catalog_info.title: Fundamentals of Computational Neuroscience
catalog_info.notes: Please enroll in Neurobiology 101 if you are interested in taking one of the sophomore tutorials.
catalog_info.description: The brain is an extremely complex computing device. Computational neuroscience seeks to understand brain function by constructing mathematical models of the nervous system to summarize our knowledge and gain new insights into how neurons perform basic tasks, e.g., encode stimuli, form memories, or generate movements. This course presents computational techniques for investigating, modeling, and understanding the function of neurons, neuronal networks, and systems. Students must complete both terms of this course(parts A and B) within the same academic year in order to receive credit.
